awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Sequential and Compound Estimation for Computational Imaging Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The widespread use of imaging technologies across biology, chemistry, material science, medicine, and other fields is motivated by the great innate human ability for visual information processing.  Imaging is often limited, however, by the damage to a sample caused by the imaging process, such as sputtering due to the incident ion or electron beam in scanned beam microscopy.  With conventional methods, a sample may be destroyed before enough information has been gained to form a useful image.  This project develops methods for reducing the necessary dose in microscopy systems.  This may make it possible to image molecular or biological species not before imaged, or to increase the speed of imaging so that new dynamic phenomena are revealed.  The project also includes dissemination of results to broad audiences through expository writing, general-audience talks, cross-disciplinary training, and production of teaching materials.
 
Poisson models are often exploited when measured signals are due to small numbers of detected particles.  A major premise of this project is to combine the Poisson modeling of such detection counts with Poisson modeling of the numbers of interacting particles in low-current beams.  The project develops theory and methods for the resulting compound estimation problems.  The project explores the use of time-resolved sensing to reduce the uncertainty due to the source shot noise in compound processes.  Furthermore, time-resolved sensing enables the decomposition of a data collection process into a sequence of less-damaging steps, and the project will develop theory and methods for sequential estimation and adaptive data collection.  Analysis will inspire and be informed by proof-of-concept experiments.  The ultimate limit of learning about a sample without damaging it is achieved with certain quantum-mechanical interaction-free measurements.  The project will develop theory for sequential interaction-free measurements to establish when they may be superior to conventional measurements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microscopes allow seeing far beyond the resolution limits of the human eye.  Standard optical microscopy is similar to photography with a telephoto lens and thus seems like a natural extension of our senses.  There are many other types of microscopy, and they depend on mechanisms for probing and measurement that are nothing like biological vision.  For example, electron microscopes use a scanned focused beam of electrons to induce backscatter, transmission, and emission of electrons, which may be detected with or without spatial or energy resolution to produce various types of images.  The wavelengths of electrons can be up to 100,000 times shorter than visible light photons, contributing to finer resolution than optical microscopy.  Using ions rather than electrons as the incident particles can enable even finer resolution, in part from lower beam diameter and greater sensitivity of surfaces to heavier particles.

The main focus of this project was to explore the fundamental informational properties of a particle beam microscope (PBM), with an emphasis on the differences between a PBM and a standard optical microscope.  Though the physical processes underlying these microscopes are vastly different, the conventional measurement mechanisms and data processing in a PBM hides these differences.  A micrograph produced by a conventional PBM contains a small fraction of the information that is measurable in principle.  The project made this information gap precise and developed methods to fully extract the available information.  Since information extraction is generally proportional to dose—the mean number of incident particles per unit area—any increase in extracted information can be translated to a reduction in imaging dose.  This can be important in imaging fragile samples such as viruses or cells.

The limits of a PBM were established based on a mathematical abstraction where beam particle incidences form a Poisson process and the sample generates a Poisson-distributed random number of secondary electrons (SEs) in response to each incident particle.  This approximate model for the mechanisms within a PBM is supported by several past empirical studies, but it was not previously studied from an informational point of view.  The key difference from optical microscopy or ordinary digital photography is that the randomness of the incident beam is a significant source of noise in the instrument measurements if one simply integrates over a pixel dwell time or exposure time.  The project introduced a new way to think about the signals within a PBM that essentially eliminates the relevance of the incident beam randomness.

To characterize fundamental limits, the project largely assumed that SEs are detected directly and accurately.  A major focus was to compare two types of data collection:  time-resolved (TR) data collection, in which the numbers of SEs detected in response to each incident particle are observed; and conventional data collection, in which only the total number of SEs detected within a pixel dwell time is observed.  This conventional data is an idealization of what is common in today's PBMs, whereas TR data represents what one could plausibly collect.

If one had a quantitative goal when forming an SE image with a PBM, that goal would be the estimation of SE yield—the mean number of SEs detected per incident particle.  The image would then be a map of the variation in SE yield over the sample.  Through analyses of Fisher information the project established that TR data is more informative than conventional data by a factor that is approximately equal to the SE yield.  Simulation of specific estimators supported this quantification of the value of TR data.  Alternatively, one can study the detection of features in a micrograph by calculating Kullback-Leibler divergence between distributions.  Through these computations, the project established that one can expect feature detection with much lower probability of error when using TR data rather than conventional data.

TR data has other attractive properties.  For example, the project showed that one can estimate the beam current of a PBM jointly with the SE yield, which is plainly not possible with conventional data.  This can be used to correct imaging artifacts due to variation in beam current, calibrate a PBM without the need for a standardized sample, and be the basis for instrument diagnostics.

Overall, the project used theoretical principles to show that the signals generated in a PBM carry much more information than what is exploited in today's instruments.  This may inspire new instrument designs.  Since the room for improvement increases with increasing SE yield, it may in particular encourage use of heavier incident particles in PBMs.
